Most people don't think of E85 as being a high performance fuel, but it truly is. It has two characterists that are of interest to high performance car enthusiasts.
 1. Octane levels of 105-106 This is equivalent to very expensive racing gas at a fraction of the cost. (E85 is currently available here in Detroit for $2.88/gallon. Racing gas is running <$10/gallon.). It has a lower natural propensity to detonate because of its high octane AND the folowing characteristic.
 2. Ethanol cools dramatically when atomized. This cools the Air/fuel charge, which reduces the tendency to detonate even further. This property also allows the use of power adders such as turbos and superchargers to be run without expensive and complicated intercoolers, giving a higher density fuel/air charge into the cylinders (thereby making additional horsepower).
 
 Since the mixture is cooler, engine killing detonation at high boost becomes less of an issue, so more timing can be put into the ignition.
 
 Redacted info. emoticon_xgood

post_info.post_title: E85 - A new High performance fuel

Most people don't think of E85 as being a high performance fuel, but it truly is. It has two characterists that are of interest to high performance car enthusiasts.
 1. Octane levels of 105-106 This is equivalent to very expensive racing gas at a fraction of the cost. (E85 is currently available here in Detroit for $2.88/gallon. Racing gas is running <$10/gallon.). It has a lower natural propensity to detonate because of its high octane AND the folowing characteristic.
 2. Ethanol cools dramatically when atomized. This cools the Air/fuel charge, which reduces the tendency to detonate even further. This property also allows the use of power adders such as turbos and superchargers to be run without expensive and complicated intercoolers, giving a higher density fuel/air charge into the cylinders (thereby making additional horsepower).
 
 Since the mixture is cooler, engine killing detonation at high boost becomes less of an issue, so more timing can be put into the ignition.
 
 My son and I are going to be taking advantage of these properties (and E85 local availability) and are building a turbocharged potentially high 7's-low 8's second 1/4 mile running streetable car capable of making <1200RWHP. emoticon_xgood
Pardon me while I clear my throat! Did you say Twelve Hundred Rear Wheel Horse Power? 1200WRHP? My, my!...on 8 cylinders?...without a Roots blower?...without afterburners?
 
 I just wanna sit down and watch that thing take off!
 
 What bore and stroke? What redline?

How do you plan to overcome the raw energy deficit of ethanol vs gasoline?
 
 76K BTU per gallon for ethanaol versus 115.5K BTU per gallon of gasoline.
 
 Detonation issues aside, you simply need burn 1.5X as much fuel to get the same power.
 
 Waxy

Pardon me while I clear my throat! Did you say Twelve Hundred Rear Wheel Horse Power? 1200WRHP? My, my!...on 8 cylinders?...without a Roots blower?...without afterburners?
 
 I just wanna sit down and watch that thing take off!
 
 What bore and stroke? What redline?

 
 Redacted classified info. ;)
 
How do you plan to overcome the raw energy deficit of ethanol vs gasoline?
 
 76K BTU per gallon for ethanaol versus 115.5K BTU per gallon of gasoline.
 
 Detonation issues aside, you simply need burn 1.5X as much fuel to get the same power.
 
 Waxy

 
 In practical terms, when racing the amount of fuel consumed is inconsequential. We raced a twin turbo car running on C16 @$11/gallon last year. We also went through over 20 pounds of ice (for the twin intercoolers) per run. That car was expensive to drive on the street, too, because it still required racing fuel to run.
 With this one, it'll use more while racing and ~25% more than gas when cruising. At $3.00/gallon, I'd have to use almost 4X as much in order for it to have the same operating cost as the last one. Since it cools when atomized, there's no need for an intercooler or 3 bags of ice per run. And on the road, the estimated 25% increase in usage is no biggie. emoticon_xgood

 In drag racing yes, fuel usage is largely inconseqential. That's obviously not so in many forms of racing. 
 
 I guess I was pondering what you planned to do on the intake side to compensate for the 25-50% more fuel, and therefore air, that you have to put through the engine to develop the same power.
 
 I take it that intake charge is not currently your limiting factor?
 
 Waxy
